2024-2025 Shepherd University Catalog

Political Science, B.S.

Print-Friendly Page (opens a new window)
Facebook this Page (opens a new window)
Tweet this Page (opens a new window)

The study of political science develops knowledge and understanding of national and international government, politics, and policy. The program prepares students for careers in public service, nonprofit organizations, international affairs, and select jobs in the private sector. It prepares students for graduate work leading to careers in a variety of areas including law, public administration, policy analysis, foreign service, journalism, and teaching. Proximity to Washington, D.C., allows enhancement of traditional classroom work with opportunities to observe the federal government in operation.

The learning outcomes of the Political Science program are as follows:


1. To facilitate student learning of core political science knowledge, skills, and values.
2. To foster global and local civic awareness and participation in all students.
3. To provide opportunities for students to engage in original research, meaningful
public service, and practical experiential learning activities.
4. To prepare students for post-graduate study and diverse employment opportunities
in the public and private sectors.

Curriculum for a Major in Political Science

Â 
Specific Core Curriculum requirements:Â  take PSCI 150 Â to fulfill First Year Experience requirement; take PSCI 100 Â to fulfill Social Sciences area.

Total hours required, 40 Hours:

Required courses, 19 Hours:

  • PSCI 200 - American Political Institutions (3cr)
  • PSCI 302 - Intro to Political Theory (3 cr)
  • PSCI 304 - Intro to Comparative Politics (3 cr)
  • PSCI 324 - International Relations (3 cr)
  • PSCI 496 - Research Design and Methods (3cr)
  • PSCI 497 - Senior Research (4cr)

Elective courses, 21 Hours:

  • Â Any 300- or 400-level course in political science**
Note(s):

**Most 300- and 400-level political science courses can only be offered every other year. Students should plan their schedules accordingly.Â 

No more than six hours of PSCI 443 Internship in Government Â can be counted toward the political science major or minor (additional internship hours will be considered as general electives).

Curriculum for a Major in Political Science, Homeland Security Concentration

The study of homeland security develops knowledge and understanding of the political and social aspects of domestic security and the global factors that influence domestic security, including law and policing, administration and policy, extremism and crime, and communication and conflict resolution. It prepares students for careers in local, state, and national government, security and law enforcement, corporate roles related to security, as well as further graduate study in security studies.

Total Hours Required, 46 Hours:

Specific Core Curriculum requirements: take PSCI 150 Â to fulfill First Year Experience requirement; take PSCI 100 Â and SOCI 203 Â to fulfill Social Sciences area.

PSCI Core, 19 Hours:

  • PSCI 200 - American Political Institutions (3cr)
  • PSCI 302 - Intro to Political Theory (3 cr)
  • PSCI 304 - Intro to Comparative Politics (3 cr)
  • PSCI 324 - International Relations (3 cr)
  • PSCI 496 - Research Design and Methods (3cr)
  • PSCI 497 - Senior Research (4cr)

Homeland Security Core, 9 Hours:

  • CRIM 200 - Introduction to Criminal Justice (3 cr)

  •  

  • PSCI 342 - Homeland Security (3cr)
  • OR  CRIM 342 - Homeland Security (3cr)

  •  

  • CRIM 360 - Ethical Practices (3cr)

Distribution Courses, 18 Hours:

  • Complete one course from Security, Law, Policing, and Society in the U.S.

  • CRIM 402 - Advanced Criminological Theory (3 cr)
  • CRIM 425 - Policing (3cr)
  • CRIM 430 - Police Organization and Management (3 cr)
  • PSCI 431 - Security and Insecurity in World Politics (3cr)
  • PSCI 450 - American Legal System (3 cr)
  • SOCI 205 - Social Problems (3 cr)
  • SOCI 321 - Social Stratification (3 cr)
  • SOCI 403 - Race and Ethnic Relations (3 cr)
  • SOCI 413 - Urban Sociology (3cr)

  •  

  • Complete one course from Government, Administration, and Policy

  • PSCI 300 - State and Local Government (3 cr)
  • PSCI 301 - Public Policy (3 cr)
  • PSCI 303 - Introduction to Public Administration (3 cr)

  •  

  • Complete one course from Extremism, Transnational Crime, and Global Security

  • CRIM 350 - Transnational Organized Crime (3cr)
  • PSCI 408 - Global Problems (3 cr)
  • PSCI 431  - Security and Insecurity in World Politics (3cr)
  • PSCI 433 - Terrorism (3cr)
  • PSCI 434 - Insurgency and Counterinsurgency (3cr)

  •  

  • Complete one course from Communication and Conflict Resolution

  • ENVS 390 - Geographic Information Systems (4 cr)
  • GLBL 350 - Cultural Competence & Engagement (3cr)
  • PSCI 306 - Introduction to Political Communication (3cr)
  • PSCI 423 - Topics in Political Communication (3cr)
Optional Emphasis

If no emphasis is selected, choose two open electives from any of the above areas, or as approved by the department.

Â 

If selecting an emphasis, complete two restricted electives from the list of choices (do not repeat earlier courses).

  • Emphasis in Cyber Security, Information, and Technology

     

    Required:

  • CIS 240 - Introduction to Cyber Security (3cr)

  • And one of

  • CIS 310 - Information Security (3 cr)
  • ENVS 390 - Geographic Information Systems (4 cr)
  • ENVS 396 - Photogrammetry and Aerial Systems (4 cr)
  • ENVS 397 - Advanced GIS and Remote Sensing (4cr)

  •  

  • Emphasis in Extremism, Transnational Crime, and Global Security

  • ANTH 316 - Forensic Anthropology (3cr)
  • CRIM 350 - Transnational Organized Crime (3cr)
  • PSCI 406 - American Foreign Policy Since World War II (3 cr)
  • PSCI 408 - Global Problems (3 cr)
  • PSCI 419 - International Human Rights (3cr)
  • PSCI 431 - Security and Insecurity in World Politics (3cr)
  • PSCI 433 - Terrorism (3cr)
  • PSCI 434 - Insurgency and Counterinsurgency (3cr)
  • GEOG 307 - Population and Development (3cr)


  • One regional course may be selected for this emphasis.

  • GEOG 400 - Geography of Latin America (3 cr)
  • GEOG 401 - Geography of Europe (3 cr)
  • GEOG 403 - Geography of Russia (3cr)
  • GEOG 407 - Geography of Asia (3 cr)
  • GEOG 408 - Geography of Africa (3 cr)
  • PSCI 424 - Contemporary Latin America (3cr)
  • PSCI 425 - Readings in Political Science (3 cr)
  • PSCI 426 - European Politics & EU (3 cr)
  • PSCI 427 - Russian and Eurasian Politics (3 cr)
  • PSCI 428 - Politics of East Asia (3 cr)
  • PSCI 429 - Comparative Politics of the Middle East (3 cr)

  •  


  • Emphasis in Security, Law, and Policing

  • CRIM 310 - Principles of Criminal Law (3 cr)
  • CRIM 320 - Criminal Court System (3 cr)
  • CRIM 402 - Advanced Criminological Theory (3 cr)
  • CRIM 415 - Gender and Crime (3cr)
  • CRIM 425 - Policing (3cr)
  • CRIM 430 - Police Organization and Management (3 cr)
  • PSCI 431 - Security and Insecurity in World Politics (3cr) Â 
  • PSCI 450 - American Legal System (3 cr)
  • PSCI 451 - Constitutional Law 1: Institutional Powers (3 cr)
  • PSCI 452 - Constitutional Law 2: Criminal Due Process (3 cr)

Notes:

Internship Options

A relevant internship from the following list can be used as an open elective or to fulfill one of the concentration area course with department approval.

  • PSCI 442 - Political Communication Internship (3-15cr)
  • PSCI 443 - Internship in Government (1-15)
  • PSCI 445 - Internship in Legal Studies (3 cr)
  • SOCI 419 - Internship in Sociology/Criminal Justice (3 cr)

Curriculum for a Major in Political Science, Legal Studies Concentration

Â Specific Core Curriculum requirements: take PSCI 150 Â to fulfill First Year Experience requirement; take PSCI 100 Â to fulfill Social Sciences (SO) area.

Total hours required, 43 Hours:

Required Courses, 19 Hours:

  • PSCI 200 - American Political Institutions (3cr)
  • PSCI 302 - Intro to Political Theory (3 cr)
  • PSCI 304 - Intro to Comparative Politics (3 cr)
  • PSCI 324 - International Relations (3 cr)
  • PSCI 496 - Research Design and Methods (3cr)
  • PSCI 497 - Senior Research (4cr)

Concentration Core Courses, 9 Hours:

  • PSCI 450 - American Legal System (3 cr)
  • PSCI 451 - Constitutional Law 1: Institutional Powers (3 cr)
  • PSCI 407 - Introduction to International Law (3 cr)

Elective Courses, 12 Hours:

  • BADM 312 - Business Law I (3 cr)
  • BADM 313 - Business Law II (3 cr)
  • BADM 320 - Employment Law (3 cr)
  • COMM 400 - Media Law and Ethics (3cr)
  • CRIM 310 - Principles of Criminal Law (3 cr)
  • CRIM 311 - Criminal Justice Procedures (3 cr)
  • CRIM 320 - Criminal Court System (3 cr)
  • CRIM 410 - Prosecution and Defense (3 cr)
  • PSCI 301 - Public Policy (3 cr)
  • PSCI 303 - Introduction to Public Administration (3 cr)
  • PSCI 402 - Jurisprudence: the Philosophy of Law (3 cr)
  • PSCI 404 - International Organization of World Governments (3 cr)
  • PSCI 409 - Special Topics in Constitutional Law (3 cr)
  • PSCI 419 - International Human Rights (3cr)
  • PSCI 445 - Internship in Legal Studies (3 cr)
  • PSCI 452 - Constitutional Law 2: Criminal Due Process (3 cr)
  • PSCI 453 - Constitutional Law 3: Freedom of Expression (3 cr)
  • PSCI 454 - Constitutional Law 4: The Religion Clauses (3 cr)
  • PSCI 455 - Constitutional Law 5: Equal Protection Issues (3cr)

Free electives, 3 Hours:

  • Any 300- or 400-level course in political science.

Four-Year Course Progression

Curriculum for a Major in Political Science, Political Communications Concentration

Specific Core Curriculum requirements:Â  take PSCI 150 Â Â to fulfill First Year Experience (FY) requirement; take PSCI 100 Â  as part of the 9cr Social Sciences (SO) area; take COMM 203 Â as part of the 6cr Humanities (HM) area.

Total Hours Required, 46 Hours:

Required Political Science Courses, 19 Hours:

  • PSCI 200 - American Political Institutions (3cr)
  • PSCI 302 - Intro to Political Theory (3 cr)
  • PSCI 304 - Intro to Comparative Politics (3 cr)
  • PSCI 324 - International Relations (3 cr)
  • PSCI 496 - Research Design and Methods (3cr)
  • PSCI 497 - Senior Research (4cr)

Required Concentration Courses, 15 Hours:

  • COMM 321 - Public Relations Principles (3cr)

  •  

  • COMM 326 - Radio Practicum (3cr)
  • OR  COMM 348 - News Practicum (3 cr)
  • OR  COMM 349 - New Media Practicum (3 cr)

  •  

  • JOUR 204 - Introduction to Journalism (3cr)
  • PSCI 306 - Introduction to Political Communication (3cr)

  •  

  • PSCI 423 - Topics in Political Communication (3cr)
  • OR  PSCI 442 - Political Communication Internship (3-15cr)

Elective Courses, 12 Hours:

At least 3 credits must be from PSCI.

  • COMM 306 - History of Advertising (3cr)
  • COMM 322 - Social Media (3cr)

  •  

  • COMM 350 - Digital Filmmaking (3 cr)
  • OR  COMM 360 - TV Production (3 cr)

  •  

  • COMM 400 - Media Law and Ethics (3cr)
  • COMM 403 - Media Studies (3 cr)
  • COMM 406 - Advertising and Imagery (3 cr)
  • COMM 435 - Media and Audience Analytics (3cr)
  • COMM 447 - Advanced Internet Media (3 cr)
  • COMM 470 - Strategic Campaigns (3cr)
  • JOUR 204 - Introduction to Journalism (3cr)
  • JOUR 310 - Media and Politics (3 cr)
  • PSCI 300 - State and Local Government (3 cr)
  • PSCI 301 - Public Policy (3 cr)
  • PSCI 305 - U.S. Congress (3 cr)
  • PSCI 307 - The U.S. Presidency (3 cr)
  • PSCI 310 - Parties, Politics, and Elections (3 cr)
  • PSCI 312 - Public Opinion and Political Behavior (3 cr)
  • PSCI 350 - Debate and Forensics (3cr) **
  • PSCI 351 - Model United Nations (3cr) **
  • PSCI 420 - Critical Political Issues (3 cr)
  • PSCI 423 - Topics in Political Communication (3cr)

Notes:

** No more than 3 hours of PSCI 350 Â or PSCI 351 Â can be counted toward the Political Science - Political Communications concentration elective requirement.

Four-Year Course Progression

Political Science, Political Communication Concentration
FALL Â  FIRST YEAR Â  Â  SPRING Â  FIRST YEAR Â 
Sub./Course No. Tier Title Credit Â  Sub./Course No. Tier Title Credit
PSCI 100* Â  Politics and Government 3 Â  PSCI 200 Â  American Political Institutions 3
PSCI 150** Â  First-Year Seminar 1 Â  Core Curriculum 1 Written English II 3
